seriesStmt.title: Digital Mitford Letters: The Mary Russell Mitford Archive

msIdentifier.collection: The letters of Mary Russell Mitford, vol. 4, 1819-1823

msDesc.head: Letter from Mary Russell Mitford to Mary Webb, 1819 December 9. We arrived at this date by checking Mitford's journal against Needham's note.-->

support.p: One sheet of paper, two surfaces photographed. Folded in half vertically to make four leaves. Four leaves written on, no address block.

condition.p: Outside edges browned, two pale brown blotches on paper that bleed through to the reverse.

handNotes.handNote: Someone, apparently other than Mitford, perhaps cataloging letters and describing them, who left grey pencil marks and numbered her letters now in the Reading Central Library's collection. This letter is not numbered but has a check mark in the top left of the first leaf. The annotator also added: [9 Dec. 1819].

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice," “sic," and “reg" to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

body.p:
Papa says my dear Friend that he half promised if the weather was open to drive over today to course--as the weather is you could not expect him, & I write chiefly to congratulate you all on the consoling opinion of Mr. Lawrence, & to enquire after my dear Eliza whose cough quite frightened Papa & whose threat of going out yesterday fairly put him
(I think my blotting paper is frozen) fairly put him in a passion. Write on Saturday & tell me how she is.--Will you tell your dear Father with my love that we have determined to send my little Stratford Bitch to Mr. Haydon & I shall not therefore trouble him for a greyhound--His seem all so good that it would be a pity to send them to a painter's room & mine being untried & very pretty will suit our Artist
without exciting so much regret in parting with her.
Mama will not I am afraid come up home till Wednesday or Thursday--she is quite well but very homesick.--

Did Papa tell you & Miss Jeremy how pretty Molly looks now she is washed--as white as swansdown & as glossy as floss silk--I wish you would come & see her.--Is Mr. Bailey with Mr. Dobbs? Don't forget to tell me.--Love to the dear Papa--the dear Eliza--the dear
Aunt Mary--the dear Miss Jeremy.--the dear Kate Wheeler--& last not least the dear Mary Webb.--

postscript.p: I had a letter yesterday from Miss James full of kind messages to you all. Poor Miss Ramsay (with whom Miss Emily went to Lisbon) is dead--the third sister who has gone off just as they were opening into Womanhood.--Sister Susan quite Well & comfortable & talking of coming to Town in the Spring.
